questions.question: Which companies are required to report earnings per share?

options.B: Public companies with common stock or potential common stock outstanding
options.C: Only companies with more than $1 billion in revenue

questions.explanation: EPS is required for public entities with common stock or potential common stock (like options, warrants, convertible securities) trading in a public market.
questions.tip: EPS required: public companies with common or potential common stock.

questions.question: Basic EPS is calculated as:

options.B: (Net income - Preferred dividends) ÷ Weighted-average common shares

questions.explanation: Basic EPS = (Net income - Preferred dividends) ÷ Weighted-average common shares outstanding. Preferred dividends reduce income available to common shareholders.
questions.tip: Basic EPS: (NI - Preferred dividends) ÷ Weighted-avg shares.

questions.question: A company had 100,000 shares at January 1. On April 1, it issued 20,000 shares. What is the weighted-average shares for the year?
questions.tip: Weight shares by months outstanding.

questions.question: Net income is $500,000. Preferred dividends are $50,000. Weighted-average common shares are 100,000. What is basic EPS?
questions.tip: Always subtract preferred dividends from net income.

questions.question: For cumulative preferred stock, in calculating basic EPS the preferred dividend deduction is:

options.B: The annual dividend requirement whether or not declared
options.C: Zero if dividends are in arrears

questions.explanation: For cumulative preferred, the current period's dividend requirement is deducted from net income whether or not declared, because cumulative dividends are owed regardless.
questions.tip: Cumulative preferred: deduct annual requirement even if not declared.

questions.question: For noncumulative preferred stock, the preferred dividend deduction in basic EPS is:

options.B: Only dividends declared during the period
options.C: The average of declared dividends over three years

questions.explanation: For noncumulative preferred, only dividends actually declared during the period are deducted. If not declared, noncumulative dividends are lost.
questions.tip: Noncumulative: deduct only what's declared.

questions.question: Diluted EPS reflects:

options.B: The worst-case EPS if all dilutive securities were converted/exercised

questions.explanation: Diluted EPS shows the worst-case (lowest) EPS assuming all dilutive convertible securities and stock options are converted/exercised.
questions.tip: Diluted EPS = worst case if all dilutive securities convert.

questions.question: A potentially dilutive security is antidilutive if:

options.B: It increases EPS or decreases loss per share when included
options.C: It has no effect on EPS

questions.explanation: A security is antidilutive if including it increases EPS (or decreases loss per share). Antidilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS.
questions.tip: Antidilutive = increases EPS (exclude from diluted).

questions.question: Under the treasury stock method for options, the assumed shares added to the denominator are:

options.B: Option shares minus shares assumed repurchased with proceeds

questions.explanation: Treasury stock method: assume options exercised, use proceeds to buy back shares at average market price. Net shares added = options exercised - shares repurchased.
questions.tip: Treasury stock method: net new shares = options - buyback.

questions.question: 10,000 options are outstanding with exercise price of $20. Average market price is $25. Under treasury stock method, how many shares are added to diluted EPS denominator?
questions.tip: Net shares = Options - (Proceeds ÷ Market price).

questions.question: Stock options are antidilutive when:

options.B: Exercise price exceeds average market price
options.C: Exercise price is below average market price
options.D: Options have more than one year until expiration

questions.explanation: When exercise price > average market price, options are 'out of the money.' Including them would reduce shares (company would buy back more than issued), which is antidilutive.
questions.tip: Exercise price > market price = antidilutive (exclude).

questions.question: Under the if-converted method for convertible bonds, diluted EPS adjustments include:

options.A: Adding shares only; no income adjustment
options.B: Adding back interest expense (net of tax) and adding shares
options.C: Subtracting interest expense and adding shares

questions.explanation: If-converted method: assume bonds converted at beginning of period. Add back interest expense (net of tax) to numerator; add converted shares to denominator.
questions.tip: Convertible bonds: add back interest (net of tax) + add shares.

questions.question: $1,000,000 of 6% convertible bonds are outstanding. Each $1,000 bond converts to 50 shares. Tax rate is 25%. What adjustments are made for diluted EPS?

options.A: Add $60,000 to numerator; add 50,000 shares to denominator
options.B: Add $45,000 to numerator; add 50,000 shares to denominator
options.C: Add $15,000 to numerator; add 50,000 shares to denominator

questions.explanation: Interest = $1,000,000 × 6% = $60,000. After-tax = $60,000 × (1 - 0.25) = $45,000 added to numerator. Shares = 1,000 bonds × 50 = 50,000 added to denominator.
questions.tip: Add interest net of tax; add converted shares.

questions.question: For convertible preferred stock in diluted EPS, the if-converted method:

options.A: Adds back preferred dividends to numerator and adds converted shares
options.B: Subtracts additional preferred dividends
options.C: Only adds shares; no numerator adjustment

questions.explanation: If-converted for preferred: don't deduct preferred dividends (add them back if already deducted) in numerator; add common shares that would be issued upon conversion to denominator.
questions.tip: Convertible preferred: add back dividends + add converted shares.

questions.question: When a stock dividend or split occurs, weighted-average shares for EPS purposes are:

options.B: Adjusted retroactively for all periods presented
options.D: Adjusted only for the current period

questions.explanation: Stock dividends and splits are applied retroactively to all periods presented for EPS comparability. This includes periods before the stock dividend/split occurred.
questions.tip: Stock dividends/splits = retroactive adjustment to all periods.

questions.question: A 2-for-1 stock split occurs after year-end but before financial statements are issued. EPS for the current year should:

options.B: Reflect the split retroactively

questions.explanation: Stock splits occurring after year-end but before issuance are reflected retroactively in EPS because they represent a change in capital structure that affects per-share metrics.
questions.tip: Post-year-end split: adjust EPS retroactively.

questions.question: Contingently issuable shares are included in diluted EPS when:

options.B: All necessary conditions are satisfied by the reporting date
options.C: There is any possibility of issuance

questions.explanation: Contingently issuable shares are included in diluted EPS only when all conditions for issuance are satisfied as of the reporting date (assuming it's the end of the contingency period).
questions.tip: Contingent shares: include if conditions met at reporting date.

questions.question: When multiple potentially dilutive securities exist, they should be included in diluted EPS:

options.B: In order from most dilutive to least dilutive

questions.explanation: Securities are ranked by their dilutive effect (per-share impact) and included from most dilutive to least dilutive. Include each until it becomes antidilutive.
questions.tip: Order: most dilutive first, stop when antidilutive.

questions.question: When a company has a loss from continuing operations, potentially dilutive securities are:

options.B: Excluded because they would be antidilutive
options.C: Included only if the company pays dividends

questions.explanation: When there's a loss, including additional shares would reduce the loss per share (making it less negative), which is antidilutive. So diluted EPS = basic EPS when there's a loss.
questions.tip: Loss = all securities are antidilutive (diluted = basic).

questions.question: On the income statement, EPS must be presented for:

options.B: Income from continuing operations and net income

questions.explanation: EPS must be presented for income from continuing operations and net income. EPS for discontinued operations may be presented on the face or in notes.
questions.tip: EPS required: continuing operations + net income.

questions.question: Treasury stock repurchases affect weighted-average shares:

options.A: By increasing shares for the full year
options.B: By decreasing shares from date of repurchase
options.D: Not at all until shares are reissued

questions.explanation: Treasury shares are not outstanding and are excluded from weighted-average shares from the repurchase date. They reduce the denominator in EPS calculations.
questions.tip: Treasury stock: reduces shares from repurchase date.

questions.question: Warrants are treated in diluted EPS calculations:

options.B: Using the treasury stock method

questions.explanation: Warrants are treated using the treasury stock method, the same as stock options. Assume exercise, use proceeds to buy back shares at average market price.
questions.tip: Warrants = treasury stock method (same as options).

questions.question: The two-class method for basic EPS is used when:

options.A: There are two classes of common stock
options.B: Participating securities that share in dividends exist

questions.explanation: The two-class method is required when participating securities exist that share in undistributed earnings. Earnings are allocated between common shares and participating securities.
questions.tip: Two-class method: used for participating securities.

questions.question: Net income $1,000,000; preferred dividends $100,000; weighted-avg shares 200,000. Options add 10,000 net shares under treasury stock method. What is diluted EPS?
questions.tip: Diluted: same numerator as basic + incremental shares.

questions.question: Required EPS disclosures include:

options.B: Reconciliation of numerators and denominators for basic and diluted EPS

questions.explanation: Disclosures include reconciliation of numerators and denominators, description of securities that could potentially dilute basic EPS in the future, and effects of subsequent stock changes.
questions.tip: Disclose: reconciliation of basic to diluted components.
